docs.lead_paragraph: New York State will continue to require health insurers to cover routine mammograms for women in their 40's, the State Health Commissioner said yesterday, even though a Federal panel of experts recently declared that the test was of unproven value for women in this age group. Although the Commissioner's statement amounts to a reiteration of current policy, she said she felt compelled to speak out in the wake of the Federal panel's decision.

headline.main: Coverage for Mammograms Backed in Albany

docs.abstract: New York State Health Comr Barbara DeBuono says state will continue to require health insurers to cover routine mammograms for women in their 40's, even though Federal panel has found tests of unproven value for women under 50 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The draconian economics of managed care cuts across class lines, as your Jan. 26 front-page article on the loss of jobs by senior doctors and nurses illustrates. When the private clinic we use became affiliated with a large, renowned hospital, experienced doctors retired, disheartened by the imposition of unrealistic controls, and computer technicians replaced nurses familiar with patients.

headline.main: Now Managed Care Cutbacks Mean That All of Us Get to Suffer

docs.abstract: Diane T North letter contends that 'draconian economics' of managed care cuts across class lines, as Jan 26 article on loss of jobs by senior doctors and nurses illustrates

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Governors' Association has decided to oppose President Clinton's plan to set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending, contending that it would saddle states with more of the cost of providing health care to poor people, state officials said today. Mr. Clinton says such limits are needed to impose fiscal discipline on the Medicaid program, which finances care for 37 million people.

headline.main: GOVERNORS OPPOSE CLINTON PROPOSAL FOR MEDICAID CAP

docs.abstract: National Governors' Association opposes Pres Clinton's plan to set firm limits on Medicaid spending; governors contend that plan will shift costs to state and local governments that they cannot afford; their views are significant because state and local governments pay 42 percent of Medicaid costs: $67 billion of $159 billion last year; bipartisan opposition to Federal cap represents political setback for Clinton's Medicaid proposal (M)
docs.snippet: The National Governors' Association has decided to oppose President Clinton's plan to set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending, contending that it would saddle states with more of the cost of providing health care to poor people, state officials...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed a $16.4 billion election-year budget today that provides spending increases for public schools, prisons and the environment, and more than a dozen modest initiatives aimed at Democratic and swing voters. After three years of cutting taxes and reining in government spending, Governor Whitman took a different approach this year. Instead of the deep spending cuts in almost every state agency that she proposed last year, she recommends that spending either remain at current levels or increase for most programs in the coming year. She would pay for much of these increases by relying on $850 million from sources available only once.

headline.main: Whitman Asks $16.4 Billion In New Budget

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman proposes $16.4 billion election-year budget that provides spending increases for public schools, prisons and environment; Whitman recommends that spending either remain at current levels or increase for most programs in coming year; says that she will pay for increases by relying on $850 million from sources available only once; photo; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed a $16.4 billion election-year budget today that provides spending increases for public schools, prisons and the environment, and more than a dozen modest initiatives aimed at Democratic and swing voters.     After...

docs.lead_paragraph: This has been the worst winter in memory for Dr. Don Wijetunge, who runs the emergency room at St. George's Hospital in South London. At times as many as 30 patients have been sprawled on gurneys outside his emergency room, waiting for treatment for things like pneumonia, heart attacks, stabbings and injuries from car accidents. Because Government financing cuts have forced St. George's to do away with many acute-care beds, Dr. Wijetunge said, these patients have had to wait -- often for 48 hours or more -- even as their conditions worsen.

headline.main: For British Health System, Grim Prognosis

docs.abstract: Doctors at St George's Hospital in London say that Government cuts have forced hospital to do away with many acute-care beds and patients have had to wait even as their conditions worsen; problems at St George's are mirrored across Britain, where cold snap and budget crisis have forced cancellation of non-emergency treatment, sent some of sickest patients on long odysseys in search of beds and wreaked havoc on system that has run on shoestring even at best of times; situation has so deteriorated that even some of system's staunchest supporters are beginning to wonder if Britain's beloved system of socialized medicine is in danger of collapse; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gary Gilbert Fryer, a former counselor and press secretary to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and a special assistant to the Yale University president since 1993, died Monday at the Yale Health Services Center in New Haven. He was 45 and lived in Woodbridge, Conn. The cause was non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, his wife, Joanne Segal Fryer, said.

headline.main: Gary Fryer, 45, a Yale U. Aide And Cuomo's Ex-Press Secretary
